text: The PM job can become a little too internal, influencing my stakeholders and getting alignment and all these things. But if you can't sell or support your own product, I don't trust you to build the product.
speaker: Kevin Yien
context: Lenny is discussing the importance of writing skills for product managers. Kevin explains that while internal alignment is important, PMs must also be able to create compelling external messaging. He believes that if a PM cannot effectively sell or support their own product to customers, they shouldn't be trusted to build that product in the first place.
text_ko: 프로덕트 매니저(PM) 일은 이해관계자(stakeholders)를 설득하고 얼라인먼트(alignment)을 맞추는 등 너무 내부적인 일에만 빠질 수 있어요. 그런데 자기 제품을 직접 팔거나 지원(support)을 할 줄 모르면 그 사람을 제품을 만드는 사람으로는 믿을 수 없어요.
text_zh: 产品经理这个工作有时候太偏内部了，就是影响各方利益相关者(stakeholders)啊，搞定大家的一致性(alignment)啊，这些事情。但是如果你连自己的产品都卖不出去或者支持不了，我真的不相信你能把产品做好。
text_es: El trabajo de PM puede volverse demasiado interno, influyendo en los stakeholders y buscando alineación y todas esas cosas. Pero si no puedes vender o dar soporte a tu propio producto, no confío en que puedas construir el producto.
key_sentence: If you can't sell your product, I don't trust you to build it.

text: We all talk about product sense. To me, it's just a fancy way of saying you can make good decisions with insufficient data. PMs need as many reps as possible in making decisions, documenting the rationale behind those decisions, and then crucially seeing the outcome of them.
speaker: Kevin Yien
context: Lenny asks Kevin whether every PM should keep a decision log. Kevin explains that product sense, which is often viewed as a mystical quality, is actually just the ability to make good decisions without complete information. He advocates for PMs to practice decision-making by documenting their reasoning and tracking outcomes to improve their judgment over time.
text_ko: 모두들 프로덕트 센스(product sense)에 대해 얘기하죠. 제겐 그게 불충분한 데이터로도 좋은 결정을 내릴 수 있다는 말을 멋있게 포장한 표현일 뿐이에요. PM들(PMs)은 결정을 내리는 연습을 가능한 한 많이 하고, 그 결정의 근거를 문서로 남기며, 무엇보다 그 결정이 실제로 어떤 결과를 냈는지를 직접 확인해 봐야 해요.
text_zh: 大家都在谈产品感觉(product sense)，在我看来，这不过是个花哨的说法，说白了就是你能在信息不够的情况下做出正确决策。产品经理需要尽可能多地练习做决策，把决策的理由记录下来，然后最关键的是要看到这些决策的结果。
text_es: Todos hablamos del sentido de producto (product sense). Para mí, es solo una forma elegante de decir que puedes tomar buenas decisiones cuando no tienes suficiente información. Los PMs necesitan practicar lo más posible tomando decisiones, documentando el por qué detrás de esas decisiones, y luego - y esto es clave - ver qué resultados dan.
key_sentence: Product sense is a fancy way of saying you can make decisions with insufficient data.

text: When you get to offer stage, I send an email and I say all the terrible things that are probably going to reinforce their fears. If you can tell them that upfront and they can read that whole email and still be equally excited to join you, find yourself a A+ hire.
speaker: Kevin Yien
context: Lenny introduces Kevin's unique hiring approach called the 'unsell email.' Kevin describes how he sends candidates an honest email at the offer stage outlining all the potential downsides and challenges of the role. His philosophy is that if someone remains equally enthusiastic after learning about these negatives upfront, they're likely to be an excellent long-term hire who won't be surprised or disappointed later.
text_ko: 오퍼 단계(offer stage)에 이르면, 저는 이메일로 아마도 그들의 걱정을 더 부추길 만한 안 좋은 점들을 전부 솔직하게 적어요. 그런 걸 처음부터 얘기해주고 그 이메일을 끝까지 읽고도 여전히 똑같이 기쁘게 합류하려 한다면, 그런 사람은 A+ 인재(A+ hire)를 찾은 거예요.
text_zh: 到了发offer这个阶段，我会发封邮件，把所有可能让他们更担心的坏消息都说一遍。如果你能提前把这些都告诉他们，他们看完整封邮件后还是一样兴奋地想加入你们，那恭喜你找到了一个A+级别的人才。
text_es: Cuando llegamos a la etapa de oferta, mando un email donde les digo todas las cosas terribles que probablemente van a confirmar sus miedos. Si puedes decirles eso de frente y pueden leer todo el email y aún así siguen igual de emocionados por unirse a ti, ahí tienes una contratación de primera.
key_sentence: If candidates read my email and remain excited, find yourself a A+ hire.

text: We are not even beneath the dust on the surface when it comes to what's going to change.
speaker: Kevin Yien
context: Lenny asks Kevin about interesting uses of AI in his work. Kevin shares a story about his 7-year-old daughter using Midjourney and asking 'Did I draw that?' after generating an image. He realizes that for her generation, AI image generation is just another tool like a crayon. Kevin uses this powerful metaphor to express how little we understand about the transformative potential of AI technology.
vocabulary_highlights: beneath the dust on the surface
text_ko: 앞으로 어떤 변화가 올지는 아직 본질에조차 닿지 못했어요.
text_zh: 说到未来的变化，我们现在掌握的那点东西连皮毛都算不上。
text_es: Ni siquiera hemos arañado la superficie de todo lo que va a cambiar.
key_sentence: We are not even beneath the dust on the surface of change.

text: When you are building a product, you have this team, engineers, designers, so much potential. The purpose of product management, not the person, but the practice, is to convert that potential into as much realized value for someone as possible, right? Minimum loss.
speaker: Kevin Yien
context: Lenny asks Kevin why he discourages people from going straight into product management roles. Kevin uses a physics analogy of potential and kinetic energy to explain his philosophy. He defines product management as the practice of converting a team's potential energy (the collective capabilities of engineers, designers, etc.) into kinetic energy (actual value delivered to customers) with minimal waste or loss.
text_ko: 제품을 만들 때 팀, 엔지니어, 디자이너 등 잠재력이 정말 많아요. 여기서 말하는 제품 관리(product management)는 사람을 가리키는 게 아니라 그 실천을 뜻하는 건데요, 목적은 그 잠재력을 가능한 한 많이 누군가에게 돌아가는 실현된 가치로 전환하는 거예요. 손실은 최소화하면서요.
text_zh: 当你在做产品的时候，你有这个团队，工程师、设计师，潜力巨大。产品管理(product management)这个实践的目的，不是说某个人，而是这套做法，就是要把这些潜力最大化地转换成对用户的实际价值，对吧？损失要最小。
text_es: Cuando estás desarrollando un producto, tienes este equipo, ingenieros, diseñadores, un potencial increíble. El objetivo de la gestión de producto, no me refiero a la persona sino a la práctica en sí, es convertir todo ese potencial en el máximo valor real posible para alguien, ¿verdad? Con la mínima pérdida.
key_sentence: Product management converts so much potential into realized value with minimum loss.

text: I think some of this is changing with the advent of large language models and the ability to actually just mimic someone else's tone. But I take inspiration from the camp of Anthony Bourdain, and he has, I'm going to butcher the exact quote but it's something like, 'If you want to know how to make good food, you have to eat a lot of food, and you have to be willing to have a bad meal every now and again.'
speaker: Kevin Yien
context: Lenny asks Kevin how to become a great writer, since Kevin believes writing skills are crucial for PMs. Kevin acknowledges that AI tools are changing the landscape but still emphasizes the importance of consuming quality content. He quotes celebrity chef Anthony Bourdain's philosophy about food - that to create good work, you must consume a lot of work, including some that isn't great, to develop your taste and judgment.
vocabulary_highlights: I'm going to butcher the exact quote
text_ko: 이런 부분은 대형 언어 모델(large language models)의 등장과 남의 말투를 실제로 그대로 흉내 낼 수 있는 능력 때문에 좀 달라지고 있는 것 같아요. 저는 앤서니 부르댕의 관점에서 영감을 받아요. 제가 정확한 말을 그대로 옮기진 못하겠지만, 요지는 “좋은 음식을 만드는 법을 알려면 음식을 많이 먹어봐야 하고, 가끔은 맛없는 식사도 감수할 줄 알아야 한다”였어요.
text_zh: 我觉得随着大语言模型(large language models)的出现，这种情况正在发生变化，现在确实可以直接模仿别人的语调了。但我还是很认同安东尼·波登那一派的观点，他有句话我可能说得不够准确，大概意思是："想要做出好吃的菜，你就得多吃，而且要做好偶尔踩雷的准备。"
text_es: Creo que esto está cambiando un poco con la llegada de los modelos de lenguaje grandes y la capacidad de imitar el tono de otra persona. Pero me inspiro en la filosofía de Anthony Bourdain, y él tiene una frase - no la voy a citar exactamente pero es algo así como: "Si quieres saber cocinar bien, tienes que comer mucho, y tienes que estar dispuesto a comerte una mala comida de vez en cuando."
key_sentence: I take inspiration from Anthony Bourdain's idea of learning through experience every now and again.

text: I explicitly do not mean read a bunch of other PM artifacts. You're not going to become a better writer by reading PRDs or whatever it is or support articles. It needs to be writing that compels. That's the theme I would go back to because that's what you're trying to do at the end of the day.
speaker: Kevin Yien
context: Lenny continues asking about Kevin's advice for becoming a better writer. Kevin clarifies that PMs shouldn't just read typical product management documents like PRDs (Product Requirements Documents) or support articles. Instead, they need to read writing that compels action - writing that moves people to do something different. This is because the ultimate goal of PM writing is to motivate and guide others toward specific actions.
vocabulary_highlights: at the end of the day
text_ko: 다른 PM 산출물(PM artifacts)을 잔뜩 읽어보라는 뜻은 분명히 아니에요. PRD들(PRDs)이나 그런 지원 문서(support articles)를 읽는다고 글쓰기 실력이 좋아지진 않아요. 사람을 사로잡는 글, 즉 읽는 이를 설득하고 행동하게 만드는 글이어야 해요. 그게 제가 계속 강조하는 핵심이에요. 결국 그게 당신이 궁극적으로 하려는 일이니까요.
text_zh: 我明确说的不是让你去读一堆产品经理的文档资料。你不可能通过读PRD（产品需求文档）或者支持文章什么的就变成更好的写手。你需要读的是那些真正打动人的文字。这就是我想强调的核心点，因为归根到底，这就是你要做的事情。
text_es: No me refiero para nada a leer un montón de documentos de gestión de producto. No vas a mejorar como escritor leyendo PRDs o lo que sea, o artículos de soporte. Tiene que ser escritura que enganche, que atrape. A eso es a lo que volvería siempre porque al fin y al cabo, eso es lo que estás tratando de lograr.
key_sentence: You won't become a better writer by reading PM artifacts; it needs to be writing that compels.
